column3: It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white—it would be dosed with borax and glycerine, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption. There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together.
column4: The department of Elzbieta received spoiled ham as a result of the numerous revolutions the flyers performed. Mixed with other meats, the spoiled ham had no distinct odor. The workers paid no attention to the sausage's conditions, and they brought in old sausage that had been rejected and was moldy and white. This was processed and made into home-use sausage. There were plenty of contaminated meats left over in storage, and rats were present around these food items. Conditions were too dark to make inspections, but the workers could feel the moisture on their hands and collect some of the dried dung of rats.

column3: The Egyptain government is believed that gods controlled everything. They could bring life and bring death. Their leaders, which are pharohs, have ultimate power over the people. At the top were the gods, such as Ra, Osiris, and Isis. Egyptians believed that the gods controlled the universe. Therefore, it was important to keep them happy. They could make the Nile overflow, cause famine, or even bring death. The Egyptians also elevated some human beings to gods. Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form. column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:  The Egyptian government was perceived as an instrument of divine control. They possessed the authority to both create and terminate life, exerting immense influence over the populace. Society was structured like a pyramid, with the gods residing atop, governed by pharaohs who were understood to have godlike attributes. This belief in the divinity of the pharaohs emboldened the people, granting them substantial responsibilities that were vital to maintaining cosmic balance and order. The power to influence the Nile's flow, manage famine, and even orchestrate death was a sacred right reserved for the divine pharaohs. Additionally, the pyramid complex became the resting place of their leaders, serving as symbols of their divine authority. The unwavering belief in the authority of the pharaohs among the Egyptian populace resulted in a high level of trust and deference bestowed upon the rulers.

column3: An ideal tragedy has a complex plot. There isn't a simple introduction, climax, and resolution. Another element of an ideal tragedy would be a character who is neither good or bad. It is just "unmerited misfortune" which the audience can relate to. The third element is that the play/poem has the correct ending. It has to go from good to bad due to a mistake made by the main character.
column4: An ideal tragedy is characterized by a intricate plot with no straightforward beginning, middle, or end. A tragic character stands outside the conventional good-versus-evil dichotomy. Instead of an overarching sense of injustice, the tragedy focuses on a character's unfortunate fate due to an avoidable lapse. The ending is crucial, moving from good to bad in a predictable manner due to a wrong decision made by the protagonist.

column3: According to Aristotle, the first element of an ideal tragedy is that it should have a complex storyline that evokes emotion in the audience. In paragraph 2, he states, "...imitate actions which excite pity and fear, this being the distinctive mark of tragic imitation. It follows plainly, in the first place, that the change of fortune presented must not be the spectacle of a virtuous man..."  Here he states that the tragedy should show complex characters with a complex storyline so the audience can feel different emotions that should be felt in a tragedy, such as pity and fear. The second element of a tragedy is that the plot should contain a man neither good nor evil whose life falls apart from a mistake. A character should not move from pure happiness to pure misfortune, or vise versa. For example, in paragraph 2, Aristotle states, "...here remains, then, the character between these two extremes — that of a man who is not eminently good and just, yet whose misfortune is brought about not by vice or depravity, but by some error of judgement or frailty. He must be one who is highly renowned and prosperous..." Throughout the paragraph Aristotle shows that a character should fall in between good and evil, which in turn can evoke more emotion in the audience rather than merely being shocked. The third element of a tragedy is that the complex storyline and plot should have the character's fortune go from good to bad, because of a greater mistake created. Aristotle continues to mention this throughout paragraph 3 as the ending should always be in misfortune or unhappiness. This is truly defined as a tragedy because of  how these types of common endings surprise the audience as it might be something unexpected.
column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:  According to Aristotle, the first essential element of an ideal tragedy is the intricate storyline that evokes strong emotions in the audience. Paragraph 2 underscores this concept, stating that tragedy should be characterized by dynamic action sequences that elicit feelings of both fear and pity. It emphasizes that the focus should remain on the progression of misfortune from a protagonist who starts on a positive path to a negative end.  Another essential feature of tragedy is the presence of a flawed character who experiences a downfall due to a significant mistake. Aristotle's paragraph 2 presents this concept with the character in between virtue and vice, showcasing a life marked by errors and setbacks. This underscores that the tragic arc should reflect a character's gradual transition between positive and negative extremes.  Finally, the intricate storyline and plot in a tragedy are understood to have an escalating trajectory, where the protagonist's fortune progressively declines due to the consequences of their actions. This rising-and-falling pattern ensures that the audience is surprised and caught off guard when the dramatic climax occurs in a tragedy, which ultimately transcends simple shock value.

column3: The Third Wave started off with just 30 students and a small experiment to show the impact of crowds. In just a few days, there were over 200 members.The author states, "Jones instructed the students on how to initiate new members...","...stopping non-members from entering the class, or other tasks...". Jones had taught the students how to initiate new members and to not associate with non-members. The students did't question this they just went along with it because they wanted to be apart of the big group; do what everyone else was doing. In the text, the author explains, "... Jones felt it was slipping out of control. He decided toerminate the movement...". Jones held a rally in which he told the students that a presidential candidate would be announced, but instead he explained that they all apart of an experiment. He also told them that he wanted to demonstrate "how people willingly create a sense of superiority over other, and how this can lead people to justify doing horrible things". Jones wanted to help the students understand how eaisly one can loose sense of right and wrong.
column4: The Third Wave started with just 30 students eager to participate and experiment with crowds. Within a few days, the number of members had surged to over 200, with individuals eager to join the movement. Jones, the leader, carefully instructed the students on how to receive and integrate new members. However, he expressed concern as the group's momentum seemed to be diminishing. Recognizing the potential for erosion, Jones decided to curtail the movement, emphasizing the importance of unity and the need to prioritize their mission.

column3: The structure of the ancient Egyptian system of government is shaped like a pyramid. At the top of the pyramid is the highest class (pharaoh) and at the bottom or the base is the lowest class (peasants, slaves, and farmers). The highest class, pharaohs, rule over everybody else. The next level down from pharaohs are powerful nolbes who profited from tributed paid to the pharaoh and priests who were responsible for pleasing the gods. The next level down from them are soldiers, physicians, and crafsmen/women. Soldiers supervise peasants, farmers, and slaves. Then there is the lowest level which is the farmers, peasants, and slaves. They were forced to work and entertain the pharaohs and nobles.
column4: The ancient Egyptian system of government is structured like a pyramid. At the apex of the pyramid is the pharaoh, representing the elite class. Below the pharaoh is the ruling class, consisting of powerful nobles and priests who gained their position through tributes. Below them are the soldiers, physicians, and craftsmen/woman. The lower class of farmers, peasants, and slaves work and provide for the elites, fulfilling their obligations in exchange for maintaining the smooth functioning of society.

column3: Three elements of an ideal tragedy as described by Aristotle are plot, pity, and fear. He also says that it should feature a character that goes from good to bad. He says that "There remains, then, the character between these two extremes — that of a man who is not eminently good and just, yet whose misfortune is brought about not by vice or depravity, but by some error of judgment or frailty. He must be one who is highly renowned and prosperous — a personage like Oedipus, Thyestes, or other illustrious men of such families." he says that actions that excite pity and fear are imitations of tragic marks. Good tragedies are defined by pity and fear, therefore a plot with neither pity nor fear is deemed weak. He also says that "A well-constructed plot should, therefore, be single in its issue, rather than double as some maintain. The change of fortune should be not from bad to good, but, reversely from good to bad." He explains how plots can be used to change fortune and display the actions of the tragedy.  He also mentions that tragedy should "feature a character who "is not eminently good and just" and who whose misfortune is brought about by "some error of judgment or frailty."
column4: Aristotle's ideal tragedy is defined by the presence of three crucial elements: plot, pity, and fear. It should feature a protagonist who transitions between states of good and bad, representing the cyclical nature of human existence. The story should prioritize a single central conflict, avoiding complexity or redundancy. Moreover, the tragic arc should lead from good to bad, with the reversal of fortunes serving as a symbol of human frailty and error. Lastly, a tragedy should feature a protagonist who is neither excessively virtuous nor wicked but yet suffers misfortune due to a flaw in judgment or character.

column3: The tragedy should show pity and fear and put it into the reader's head. The tragedy should also implement a major drop into the character's life or mistake. And the character should also be relatable because this is what strikes fear into the reader's mind.

column3: One element of an ideal tragedy would be that the main character is neither too good or too evil so that the audience has pity for that character. For example, if a bad person reached their downfall in the story, the audience would feel satisfaction rather than sympathy. Another element would be that that the change of fortune needs to be from good to bad because of a misjudgement. This is done in order to again ensure that the audience feels pity for the character. Lastly, a third element would be that the character has to start off as a respected and wealthy person so that there is room for the character to 'fall'.
column4: An ideal tragedy requires a protagonist who could be interpreted as morally ambiguous or neutral. This ambiguity is critical because it creates a sense of pity and empathy from the audience. Additionally, the transformation of the protagonist should flow from good to evil, highlighting the consequences of poor decision-making. Finally, the protagonist should start out with an aura of respect and wealth, emphasizing that even a tragic downfall is not a simple reversal of events but rather a gradual erosion of their perceived power and self-worth.

column4: The passage is about the process of cleaning spoiled food products. The passage mentions several methods used to remove the smell, color, and taste of the products, and also discusses the process of mixing spoiled food products with other food products.

column3: The structure of the ancient Egyptian system was the higher class citizens were treated better and worshiped. And the lower class citizens were treated badly. But everyone did work. The government needed each social class for many dfferent reasons. They needed slaves to make buildings and work on projects. Without them the people wouldnt have as many buildings. The government also needed pharoghs to rule. They needed soldiers to protect the people. The government needed the middle class to make useful items for others. They even needed the farmers because if they didnt have the farmers then the the fields wouldnt be tended the waters and resevoir wouldnt be in order and no one would of raised the animals. Every class  did something  that the government needed and if even one class didnt do there work then the government might have not been able to work.
column4: The ancient Egyptian system was structured in a way that honored social class. Upper-class citizens were treated better and worshipped more than lower-class citizens. All members of society worked together for the common good. The government required different social classes for various purposes. They needed slaves to construct buildings and work on projects, but without them, they would not have nearly as many buildings. Additionally, the government needed pharaohs to rule. They formed the military that protected the people, and they also needed the middle class to create items that others needed. Farmers were integral to the economy, as they tended fields, raised animals, and maintained water sources, all of which were necessary for the survival of the people.

column3: In the Egyptian system of the government, there are many social classes. Let me break it down for you!  The gods are very high at the pyramid because the Egyptians belived they controlled the universe. Also they belived their leaders, Pharaohs were gods in human form. In paragraph 2 it states "Their leaders, called pharaohs, were belived to be gods in human form". Next up was the cheif minister, also called a vizier. The vizier was like a supervisor and ensured taxes were paid. Working with them were scribes. In the text it states "Working with the vizier were scribes who kept goverment records. These high-level employees had mastered a rare skill in acient Egypt -- they could read and write".Next is nobles and priests. "Only nobles could hold goverment posts, in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the paraoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods." reads the text. Following up, middleish class, there were soilders who supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves. Then there were skilled workers like craftsmen, physicians and women. Lastly at the bottom, the worst you could be, is a farmer or slave. They were treated horribley. That is the social classes!
column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:  "The Egyptian government operates on a hierarchical structure, where social class is determined by a combination of factors.  The gods, worshipped by the ancient Egyptians, were believed to hold a significant position in this hierarchical structure. Pharaohs were considered gods in human form, wielding immense power and influence over the populace. The role of the vizier, another senior official, was to oversee the collection and distribution of taxes, ensuring the populace's compliance with the state.  Moreover, scribes played a crucial role in managing the administrative records of the government. Skilled scribes, with an exceptional ability to read and write, were highly respected and held prominent positions. The nobles, often highly positioned, profited from tributes and were granted the authority to govern, exercising their wealth and influence on the society. Priests were responsible for mediating between the people and the gods, bridging communication channels and ensuring the populace adhered to the religious and moral principles of Egyptian society.

column3: Within the excerpt it is explained thouroghly explained that the meat industry's qrotesque  lack of sanitation. From canning rotten meat or turning it into other "sellable" products such as sausage, they let nothing but sanitation go to waste (Paragraph 1). In order to hide the smell, color and flavor of the meat they would pickle the meat. Workers were left to do all the dirty work as they would be "plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them( paragraph 2)."
column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:    "Explanation of the meat industry's lack of sanitation is clearly laid out in the passage. Meat processing involves a large amount of handling, and therefore, proper sanitation is essential. Yet, the passage depicts a chaotic and unsanitary process where meat is handled without proper sanitation, resulting in spoiled meat, which is concealed by the processing and packaging of food products."

column3: The workers at the bottom of the class did all the durty work for the higher classes, "In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles." The upper class were nobles and priests there jobs were to please the gods, "Nobles enjoyed great status and also grew wealthy from donations to the gods." (7) They took the gifts from others and gave that to the gods not much work. Lastly the pharaoh's they were thought of as gods, "Egypt believed that their pharaohs were gods." They were worshiped as gods and had complete power.
column4: The lower-class workers, who occupied the bottom rung in society's ladder, were burdened with the most tedious and dirty tasks to fulfill the needs of the higher classes. They toiled in the construction of buildings, regardless of their social status, in addition to working on various agricultural tasks like farming crops or raising animals. They played a crucial role in maintaining the infrastructure of the kingdom, ensuring proper functioning of canals and reservoirs.  While the lower class relied on manual labor the middle and upper classes were involved in more capitalistic pursuits. The middle class, composed of merchants and artisans, engaged in trading activities and possessed the ability to engage in lucrative endeavors. In contrast, the upper class, comprised of the elite and clergy, held positions that demanded significant skill

column3: Meat packing factories would take spolied meat and reblend it with fresh meat with fresh meat after they spread the meat with chemicals and fill it with pickling vinger. " Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference." The quote backs up the argument that meat packing foctory in the early 20th century would reuse and try to cover up spoiled meat.
column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:  "Meat packing factories often resorted to blending spoiled meat with fresh meat or using chemicals to cover up the smell and flavor of spoiled meat. The process was so efficient that it produced very little odor compared to fresh meat."
